SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 3 topic or subject area.
Content: What does the words “assistant” mean as it is used in paragaraph 2?

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: Which sentence from the passage shows a cause and effect relationship?

A.Choice: “But there is one parrot who speaks more than a hundred words and actually understands their meanings.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “Teaching Alex to speak words that he understands has let Irene talk to him directly.” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “In this way, Irene is finding out what sorts of things Alex's brain can do.” (paragraph 3)

D.Choice: “He can also make comparisons, such as bigger or smaller and same or different, between objects.” (paragraph 4)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 3 topic or subject area.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 4.
:box:Alex can identify over forty kinds of objects, five different shapes, five materials, and seven colors, and he can use his knowledge to solve problems and answer questions.
What is the best meaning of the word “identify” as used in this sentence?

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Use information gained from illustrations (e.g., maps, photographs) and the words in a text to demonstrate understanding of the text (e.g., where, when, why, and how key events occur).
Content: How does the photograph add to the information in the passage?

A.Choice: It shows one way that Irene works with Alex.

B.Choice: It shows that Irene does not talk with Alex.

C.Choice: It shows that Alex is able to count objects.

D.Choice: It shows the few objects that Alex cannot name.

SubTopics: Use text features and search tools (e.g., key words, sidebars, hyperlinks) to locate information relevant to a given topic efficiently.
Content: Which part of the passage best shows how Alex feels about Irene?

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: Which detail best supports the main idea of the passage?

B.Choice: Alex can find a green object when asked.

C.Choice: Irene sometimes puts Alex on her shoulder.

D.Choice: Alex has a croaky parrot voice.

SubTopics: Determien the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.
Content: In parpagraph 1, what does Stella mean when she says, “I feel like a spider in a web”?

B.Choice: Stella is confused by the strings.

C.Choice: Stella is surrounded by the tangled strings.

D.Choice: Stella is winding the strings around her spool.

SubTopics: Distinguish their own point of view from that of the narrator or those of the characters.
Content: In paragraphs 6 through 8, what do you know as the reader that Robby does not know?

A.Choice: Stella wishes she could trade her kite for a jellyfish kite.

B.Choice: Stella has to run to make her kite fly.

C.Choice: Paper plate kites are easier to fly than other kites.

D.Choice: Paper plate kites are easier to make than shark kites.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 3 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 8.
:box:If she could catch a tiny breeze, her kite would fly.
What does “catch” mean as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: stop and hold a moving object

B.Choice: bring in while hunting or fishing

SubTopics: Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and expalin how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
Content: What happens after Stella trips over the shark's fin and falls into the dirt?

A.Choice: Stella tries to fly her kite again.

B.Choice: Stella takes Robby's paper plate home with her.

C.Choice: Stella's kite points downward and refuses to fly.

D.Choice: Stella points at a kite shaped like a monster truck.

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: What do the details in paragraph 17 show about Robby?

A.Choice: He is at the park most weekends.

B.Choice: He is a thoughtful friend to Stella.

C.Choice: He is better at flying kites than Stella.

D.Choice: He is creative with paper plates.

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: What happens because Stella cannot fly her shark kite?

A.Choice: Stella tries to fix her kite.

B.Choice: Stella notices a pink jellyfish kite.

C.Choice: Stella gets into the car with her mother.

D.Choice: Stella tries the paper plate kite.

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: How does paragraph 3 connect to paragraph 4 of “How We Use Glass”? Use two details from the pasage to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: How do the details in paragraph 5 support the main idea of “How We Use Glass”? Use two details from the passage to support your response.

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Use information gained from illustrations (e.g., maps, photographs) and the words in a text to demonstrate understanding of the text (e.g., where, when, why, and how key events occur).
Content: How does the picture of the great horned owl support the information in the passage? Use two details from the passage to support your response.

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Describe the logical connection between particular sentences and paragraphs in a text (e.g., comparison, cause/effect, first/second/third in a sequence).
Content: How are paragrpahs 3,7, and 9 of “The Great Horned Owl” alike? Use two details from the passage to support your response.

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: In “The Great Horned Owl,” how are the ideas in paragraphs 4 and 10 related? Use two details from the passage to support your response.

SubTopics: Refer to parts of storeis ,dramas, and poems when writing or speaking about a text, using terms such as cahpter, scene, or stanza; describe how each successive part builds on earlier sections.
Content: How is paragraph 12 important to “[Excerpt from] Jumanji”? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: How do Peter's feelings about the game change from the beginning of “[Excerpt from] Jumanhi” to the end? What causes Peter's feelings to change? Use detials from the story to support your response.

:box:In your response, be sure to

• describe how Peter feels about the game at the beginning of the story
• describe how Peter feels about the game at the end of the story
• explain what causes Peter's feelings to change
• use details from the story to support your response
